Economic and infrastructural planning of an area should be done bearing in mind the environment conservation. To what extent do you agree with this statement? Provide reasons for your answer.

The term Economy possess a diverse meaning, which includes every day activities of human beings, there interaction within themselves and with the physical components of the environment surrounding them. Many economists describe economy in simple terms as utilisation of natural resources tro meet the demands of of community on whole. it generally includes the transactional activities, social welfare programmes, manufacturing processes, distribution of goods and services to meet the demand. Economy of a country depends on the effective production of required goods and services and their distribution. This requires proper planning and utilisation of human force and tangible goods. The elements of and economy range from small scale industries to major manufacturing units. These are the basis for the development of a country. Along with production of materials, proper distribution channels are necessary which are mostly dependent of the imfrastructure of the community or an area.

  Economy planning requires analysing the requirements, needs, demands that particular community, accessing the availability of factors of production, then acquiring proper financial muscle and capital investment and others pre-production processes. After the production stage distribution, advertising, marketting are the prime important jobs to b carried out. these include back-end and front-end processes like transporatation, storage facilities, electricity, water facility etc. Infrastructure planning takes the pivotal role to efficiently handle the distribution channel from the producer to the end user. The satisfaction of the consumer gives the end result of whole process. the cyclic flow of goods and services, financial transactions, exports and imports add to the economic growth. For example establishing a cloth factory fulfils the need of outfits and a hospital can ensure the healthy wellbeing of a community in an area.

 Planning should be intended with a motive for the overall development of the society and earning profits. However the growth of economy of a country should be inclined to sustainable way. It should protect the rights and interests of community. Environment Conservation is the major aspect of any planning body. It take into considearation the effects of economic planning on the environment. natural resources are the biggest gift to the planet Earth. Over-utilisation or mis-utilisation cause damage to the environment, which further effects the production process in later stages. Few resources are replenishable and few are not. It is task of the planning bady to carefully examine the type of resources, their avialability and usage. this is mainly importtant for scare resoures. Also inefficient methods of extraction resources damage the harmony of balanced communities causing pollution which inturn results in health hazards, natural hazards.

Rapid use of resources and technology by developed countries to win the race and inefficient methods adopted by developing and under-developed countries due to lack of awareness and technical expertise bas largely effected the planet on whole. This resulted in rise of global warming, hazards, displacement of natural habitat, extinction of various species  and other environmental issues. For example nucler hazard of Fukushima Nuclear Plant, Bhopal gas tragedy has taken the lives of many and caused lot of damage to the property and human settlements. Over utilisation might also replenish the resources which have to be passed on to future.

 Therefore it is neccesary to have a proper Environment Accessment report based on the pros and cons of an economic activity to be undertaken. It should involve the assent of projects with best and eco-friendly processes, effects to underlying communities, compensation etc. The analysed report should be held for the consensus of the related communities so as to gain the dissent over societal issues and their local sentiments. For which the communities need awarness regarding the project. Attached ministries should throughly check the effects of the project on whole economy and then give its approval.As the very basic fact is that the main source of the resources is the nature, thereby protecting the same will sustain the humankind for long.

June 2013 – Global Auto Industry Outlook

The auto industry is highly concentrated. The top 10 global automakers account for roughly 80% of the worldwide production and nearly 90% of total vehicles sold in the U.S.

In the first five months of 2013, General Motors Company ( GM ) led with a 18.0% market share in the U.S., followed by Ford Motor Co. ( F ) with a 16.4% market share, Toyota Motors Corp. ( TM ) with a 14.2% market share, Chrysler-Fiat with a 11.7% market share, and Honda Motor Co. ( HMC ) and Nissan Motor Co. ( NSANY ) at the last spots with 9.5% and 8.1% market shares, respectively.

Toyota recaptured the sales crown from General Motors by selling 9.75 million vehicles globally in 2012, which exceeded GM`s sales of 9.29 million vehicles. Germany`s Volkswagen AG ( VLKAY ) came third with sales of 9.07 million vehicles for the year.

OPPORTUNITIES

To remain competitive, the automakers will need to design vehicles that will cater to consumers in both mature and emerging markets while manufacturing them at low-cost using the most advanced technology.

For example, Ford has undertaken "One Manufacturing" strategy, which aims at producing multiple models from plants across the world in order to save production costs and fast adaptation to changes in consumer tastes. The automaker anticipates producing 4.5 models at each of its plants by 2015, up from 3.6 models currently.

Further, the automakers are concentrating on offering more optional features (which will save money on gas), even on the small and less gas-guzzler vehicles in order to attract buyers. The sale of optional features is helping them offset lower profit margins for small cars relative to large trucks.

The automakers continue to shift their production facilities from high-cost regions such as North America and the European Union to lower-cost regions such as China, India and South America. According to a study by CSM Worldwide, China and South America together will represent more than 50% of growth in global light vehicle production in the auto industry from 2008 to 2015.

The role of governments is highly significant. Their energy and environmental policies will be strongly responsible in molding the auto industry in the coming years. In late 2011, 13 major automakers, including Ford, GM, Chrysler, BMW, Honda, Hyundai, Jaguar/Land Rover, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Toyota and Volvo, have signed letters of commitment with the U.S. Government to upgrade the fuel economy standard of cars and light-duty trucks to 54.5 miles per gallon (mpg) by 2025.
